Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

a) Hot Water System Ratio (HWSR) baseline is 1.45 Compliance 

b) Provision of permanent measuring instruments for monitoring of Hot Water System Ratio 
 
c) Measure Heat loss from Hot Water system, can be from third party energy audit or permanent M&V

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa
Hot_Water_System_Ratio:
a) Hot Water System Ratio (HWSR) baseline is 1.45 Compliance 

b) Provision of permanent measuring instruments for monitoring of Hot Water System Ratio 
 
c) Measure Heat loss from Hot Water system, can be from third party energy audit or permanent M&V

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.
ELECTRICAL_SUBMETERING_REQUIREMENT:
People moving: Sum of all feeder > 50kVA
Lighting: Connected load > 50kVA
Process and plug loads: Connected loads > 50kVA
Process loads: Connected gas or district services load > 75kW
Lighting_Power_Budget:
Offices: ≤ 12W/m² 
Meeting Room: ≤ 12W/m² 
Copt/Print Rooms: ≤ 12W/m² 
Classrooms: ≤  12W/m² 
Lecture Theatre: ≤  12W/m² 
Computer Rooms: ≤ 12W/m² 
Reading Areas: ≤  12W/m² 
Laboratories: ≤  16W/m² 
Entrance Hall: ≤  10W/m² 
Atriums: ≤  10W/m² 
Retail Atriums: ≤ 10W/m² 
Retail Corridors (Interior): ≤ 7W/m² 
Concourse: ≤ 10W/m² 
Lobby: ≤ 10W/m² 
Auditorium: ≤ 10W/m² 
Concert Hall: ≤ 10W/m² 
Multi Purpose Hall: ≤ 16W/m² 
Conference Hall: ≤ 16W/m² 
Retail (General Lighting): ≤ 15W/m² 
Retail - Jewellery (Total): ≤ 35W/m² 
Retail - Furniture, clothing & accessories, cosmetics, art (Total): ≤ 25W/m² 
Retail - Supermarket, vehicle, sporting goods, stationary, hardware, others (Total): ≤ 20W/m² 
Food Courts & Hawker Centres: ≤ 10W/m² 
Canteens: ≤ 10W/m² 
Restaurants: ≤ 12W/m² 
Lounges: ≤ 12W/m² 
Bars: ≤ 12W/m² 
Corridors: ≤ 7W/m² 
Stairs, Escalators, Travellators: ≤ 6W/m² 
Lift Lobbies: ≤ 7W/m² 
Warehouses: ≤ 7W/m² 
Storage Areas: ≤ 10W/m² 
Carpark: ≤ 3W/m² 
Hotel Guest Rooms: ≤ 12W/m² 
Toilets: ≤ 10W/m² 
Changing Rooms: ≤ 10W/m² 
Laundries: ≤ 10W/m² 
Washing Areas: ≤ 10W/m² 
Gymnasium & Physical Excercise Areas: ≤ 11W/m² 
Mechanical & Electrical Rooms: ≤ 10W/m² 
Manufacturing (general): ≤ 13W/m² 
Manufacturing (electronic, fine detail or assembly): ≤ 14W/m²
Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

Integrated_Energy_Management_And_Control:
(i) Energy Consumption Monitoring and benchmarking system 
Tracking a building’s energy use with the data presented in a relevant manner to engage its occupants can have an effect in helping to manage building energy consumption. Related to this ideal of sharing building data openly is the need to apply open standards to future-proof the building’s management system and to facilitate data exchange between subsystems.

(ii)Lighting Demand Control
Occupancy/vacancy sensing: Control automatically turns light off when motion is no longer detected and shall be provided in accordance with SS 530: 2014 Code of Practice for Energy efficiency Standard for Building Services and Equipment. In hotel buildings, a control device shall be installed in every guestroom to automatically switch off the lighting when unoccupied.

(iii) ACMV Demand Control
utomatic controls for the air-conditioning system to respond to periods of non-use, or reduced heat load using the following:
• Occupancy-based sensing: Control is exercised based on measured occupancy, e.g. number of occupants.
• In hotel buildings, a control device shall be installed in every guestroom to automatically reduce the air-conditioning loads when a guestroom is not occupied.
• Location plans of the relevant sensors demonstrating that at least 80% of the applicable areas are covered
• Specifications of the sensors and a method statement of the ACMV controls including the sensor regulation of temperature and fresh air supply

Integrated_Energy_Management_And_Control:
(i) Energy Consumption Monitoring and benchmarking system 
Tracking a building’s energy use with the data presented in a relevant manner to engage its occupants can have an effect in helping to manage building energy consumption. Related to this ideal of sharing building data openly is the need to apply open standards to future-proof the building’s management system and to facilitate data exchange between subsystems.

(ii)Lighting Demand Control
Occupancy/vacancy sensing: Control automatically turns light off when motion is no longer detected and shall be provided in accordance with SS 530: 2014 Code of Practice for Energy Efficiency Standard for Building Services and Equipment. In hotel buildings, a control device shall be installed in every guestroom to automatically switch off the lighting when unoccupied.

(iii) ACMV Demand Control
Automatic controls for the air-conditioning system to respond to periods of non-use, or reduced heat load using the following:
• Occupancy-based sensing: Control is exercised based on measured occupancy, e.g. number of occupants.
• In hotel buildings, a control device shall be installed in every guestroom to automatically reduce the air-conditioning loads when a guestroom is not occupied.
• Location plans of the relevant sensors demonstrating that at least 80% of the applicable areas are covered
• Specifications of the sensors and a method statement of the ACMV controls including the sensor regulation of temperature and fresh air supply

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

Integrated_Energy_Management_And_Control:
(i) Energy Consumption Monitoring and benchmarking system 
Tracking a building’s energy use with the data presented in a relevant manner to engage its occupants can have an effect in helping to manage building energy consumption. Related to this ideal of sharing building data openly is the need to apply open standards to future-proof the building’s management system and to facilitate data exchange between subsystems.

(ii)Lighting Demand Control
Occupancy/vacancy sensing: Control automatically turns light off when motion is no longer detected and shall be provided in accordance with SS 530: 2014 Code of Practice for Energy Efficiency Standard for Building Services and Equipment. In hotel buildings, a control device shall be installed in every guestroom to automatically switch off the lighting when unoccupied.

(iii) ACMV Demand Control
Automatic controls for the air-conditioning system to respond to periods of non-use, or reduced heat load using the following:
• Occupancy-based sensing: Control is exercised based on measured occupancy, e.g. number of occupants.
• In hotel buildings, a control device shall be installed in every guestroom to automatically reduce the air-conditioning loads when a guestroom is not occupied.
• Location plans of the relevant sensors demonstrating that at least 80% of the applicable areas are covered
• Specifications of the sensors and a method statement of the ACMV controls including the sensor regulation of temperature and fresh air supply

Integrated_Energy_Management_And_Control:
(i) Energy Consumption Monitoring and benchmarking system 
Tracking a building’s energy use with the data presented in a relevant manner to engage its occupants can have an effect in helping to manage building energy consumption. Related to this ideal of sharing building data openly is the need to apply open standards to future-proof the building’s management system and to facilitate data exchange between subsystems.

(ii)Lighting Demand Control
Occupancy/vacancy sensing: Control automatically turns light off when motion is no longer detected and shall be provided in accordance with SS 530: 2014 Code of Practice for Energy Efficiency Standard for Building Services and Equipment. In hotel buildings, a control device shall be installed in every guestroom to automatically switch off the lighting when unoccupied.

(iii) ACMV Demand Control
Automatic controls for the air-conditioning system to respond to periods of non-use, or reduced heat load using the following:
• Occupancy-based sensing: Control is exercised based on measured occupancy, e.g. number of occupants.
• In hotel buildings, a control device shall be installed in every guestroom to automatically reduce the air-conditioning loads when a guestroom is not occupied.
• Location plans of the relevant sensors demonstrating that at least 80% of the applicable areas are covered
• Specifications of the sensors and a method statement of the ACMV controls including the sensor regulation of temperature and fresh air supply

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

Process loads: Connected gas or district services load > 75kW

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa
EUI_Solution_LOW_COST:
a. Conduct regular energy audit to identify areas of inefficiency

b. Implement and train energy saving practices among staff and users

c. Design the building to maximize natural lighting and ventilation
EUI_Solution_AVG_COST:
a. Install smart energy management system
(i) Schneider, EcoStruxure

b. Upgrade to LED lighting with daylight and occupancy sensors

c. Implement a building energy mangement system
(i) Honeywell, Enterprise Buildings Integrator

d. Install energy submetering for different zones

e. Install an advanced building analytics platform
(i) BuildingIQ
EUI_Solution_HIGH_COST:
a. Implement a Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) system
(i) Daikin, VRV IV

b. Install high efficiency chillers with heat recovery
Trane, Series E

c. Install a large scale solar PV system

d. Implement a microgrid system with AI driven energy optimization
Air_Side_Efficiency_Solution_LOW_COST:
a. Optimize air handling unit (AHU) schedules based on occupancy patterns

b. Implement regular maintenance and cleaning of HVAC components

c. Optimize air distribution through proper zoning and balancing

d. Implement a comprehensive air quality management plan

e. Design for maximum natural ventilation in common areas
Air_Side_Efficiency_Solution_AVG_COST:
a. Install Variable Speed Drives (VSD) on AHU fans
(i) ABB ACH580

b. Upgrade to high efficiency air filters
(i) Camfil, Hi Flo XLT
c. Install demand controlled ventilation with CO2 sensors.

d. Implement an advanced AHU control system
(i) Siemens Desigo CC

e. Install ultra low pressure drop air distribution

f. Implement advanced airflow measurement and control system
(i) EBTRON GTx116P
Air_Side_Efficiency_Solution_HIGH_COST:
a. Implement a demand controlled ventillation with CO2 sensors

b. Install energy recovery (ERVS)

c. Install a dedicated outdoor air system (DOAS)

d. Implement displacement ventilation in large spaces like auditoriums

e. Install an AI driven HVAC optimization system
ETTV_Solution_LOW_COST:
a. Use light colored exterior finished to reflect solar radiation

b. Optimise building orientation to minimize solar heat gain

c. Implement strategic landscaping for natural shading

d. Optimize building form to minimize surface area to sun

e. Use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) for optimal building envelope design

f. Implement biophillic design principles for natural cooling
ETTV_Solution_AVG_COST:
a. Install external shading devices

b. Apply solar control window filmd
(i) 3M Prestige Series

c. Install dynamic glazing
(i) View, Dynamic Glass

d. Develop a bio  responsive facade with living components
ETTV_Solution_HIGH_COST:
a. Upgrade to triple glazed low E windows

b. Implement a double skin facade with ventilated cavity

c. Install Vacuum Insulated Panels (VIPs) in walls

d. Upgrade to double glazed windows (low E)
(i) Guardian, SunGuard
ACMV_TSE_Solutions_LOW_COST:
a. Implement optimal start or stop strategies for HVAC systems

b. Conduct regular maintenance and optimization of chiller plants

c. Use data analytics for continuous HVAC optimization

d. Implement advanced chiller sequencing strategies

e. Design for minimal reliance on mechanical cooling

f. Implement predictive maintenance strategies for all ACMV systems
ACMV_TSE_Solutions_AVG_COST:
a. Upgrade to high efficiency chillers 
(i) Trane, Series E, CenTraVac

b. Install variable speed drives on pumps and cooling tower fans
(i) Danfoss, VLT HVAC Drive FC 102

c. Install magnetic bearing chillers 
(i) Danfoss, Turbocor

d. Install an AI driven predictive HVAC control system
(i) BuildingIQ, 5i Platform
ACMV_TSE_Solutions_HIGH_COST:
a. Install a heat recovery chiller
(i) Carrier, 19XRE

b. Develop a district cooling connection for the hotel

Implement a comprehensive energy recovery system
(i) Konvekta Ultra-efficient Heat Recovery

c. Develop a fully renewable powered cooling solution with thermal storage
Rooms_Receiving_Natural_Ventilation_in_a:
a. Design room layouts to maximize cross ventilation

b. Educate users on the benefits of natural ventilation

c. Design atrium spaces to enhance natural airflow

d. Implement a natural ventilation usage policy for the center

e. Utilize CFD for optimal natural ventilation design.

a. Install operable windows with limiters for safety

b. Implement ceiling fans in a naturally ventilated room
(i) Big Ass Fans, Haiku

c. Implement advanced air quality monitoring in natural ventilated areas

d. Implement advanced thermal comfort monitoring and feedback system

a. Install automated window systems linked to BMS

b. Implement personalized ventilation systems in the room

c. Create wind corridors in building design for enhanced airflow

d. Implement an AI driven natural ventilation optimization system
Lighting_LOW_COST:
a. Implement a comprehensive lighting control policy

b. Maximize use of natural daylight through strategic space planning

c. Develop and implement a comprehensive daylight harvesting strategy

d. Train users on efficient lighting practices

e. Design spaces to maximize daylight penetration and minimize glare

f. Implement an ultra low Lighting Power Density LPD strategy
Lighting_AVG_COST:
a. Replace all lighting with LED fixtures

b. Install occupancy sensors in low traffic areas

c. Implement daylight harvesting systems with auto dimming 
(i) Lutron, Energi TriPak

d. Install human centric lighting system in key areas

 e. Install advanced daylight redirection system
(i) 3M, Daylight Redirecting Film

f. Implement task ambient lighting strategies with personalized controls
Lighting_HIGH_COST:
a. Implement a centralized lighting control system

b. Install tunable white lighting for improved circadian rhythms

c. Install a Power over Ethernet PoE Lighting System
(i) Cisco Digital Building Series

d. Implement an AI-driven lighting optimisation system

e. Integrate lighting systems with building management and IoT platforms for holistic control

f. implement dynamic façade systems that optimize daylight and artificial lighting
(i) Somfy, Digital Network

Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

PERMANENT_INSTRUMENTATION_FOR_MEASUREMEN:
(i) Chilled Water Air Conditioning System
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 1-minute sampling time interval, recorded to the 3rd decimal digit. 

• Building Management System (BMS), standalone Energy Monitoring System (EMS) or local sequential controller shall have the capability to compute and display key indicators such as water-side, air-side and total system efficiency and calculated heat balance of the chilled water system. 

• Magnetic in-line flow meter, with 1% uncertainty, and capable of electronic in-situ verification to within ±2% of its original factory calibration. If installation of magnetic in-line meters is not possible, ultrasonic flow meters or other flow meters that can meet the indicated performance may be used. 

• Temperature sensors are to be provided for chilled water and condenser water loop and shall have an end-to-end measurement uncertainty not exceeding ±0.05°C over the entire measurement range. Provisions shall be made for test-plugs or additional thermowells to be installed before and after each temperature sensor along the chilled water and condenser water lines for verification of measurement accuracy. All thermo-wells are recommended to be installed in a manner that ensures the sensors can be in direct contact with the fluid flow. There shall be valid justification if direct immersion of the temperature sensor(s) is/are not possible. Such projects will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. 

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers, where applicable, of Class 1 or better, are to be provided for each of the following groups of equipment: chillers, chilled water pumps, condenser water pumps, cooling towers, air distribution system (i.e. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• A heat balance substantiating test for the water-cooled chilled-water system is to be computed in accordance with SS 591 for verification of the accuracy of the M&V instrumentation. The heat balance shall be computed over the entire normal operating hours with more than 80% of the computed heat balance within ± 5% over a 1-week period. Heat balance readings should be generated automatically from BMS/BAS. 


(ii) VRF system
• Data logging with the capability to trend at 5-minute sampling time interval, recorded to at least one decimal place. 

• Building management system (BMS), standalone energy monitoring system (EMS) shall have the capability to compute and display the overall system energy efficiency to facilitate data extraction for verification purpose.  

• Dedicated power meters (of IEC Class 1 or better) and metering current transformers (of Class 1 or better) where applicable, are to be provided for all condensing units of the VRF system and air distribution sub-systems (e.g. AHUs, PAHUs, FCUs).  

• VRF Suppliers’ in-house monitoring system is acceptable if it’s capable of monitoring the system efficiency within 10% uncertainty.

People moving: Sum of all feeder > 50kVA
Lighting: Connected load > 50kVA

Process loads: Connected gas or district services load > 75kW

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa

Mechanical_Ventilation:
At least 10% more energy efficient than the stated Baseline standard

Baseline Standard for Mechanical Ventilation System for Normally Occupied Spaces
OPTION 1(Allowable Fan system motor nameplate motor): 0.35W/CMH 
OPTION 2(Allowable Fan system input Power): ≤ 0.3 + A* W/CMH
* Sum of the pressure drop adjustments (in Pa) divided by 2340that can be considered according to the recommendation provided in Table 2b of SS 553 and are subject to BCA's evaluation. (PD/2340)

Table 2b
Fully ducted return and/or exhaust air systems = 125Pa (535 Pa for laboratory and vivarium systems)
Return and/or exhaust airflow control devices = 125Pa
Exhaust filters, scrubbers, or other exhaust treatment = The pressure drop of device calculated at fan system design condition
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 9-12 = 125Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 13-15 = 225Pa
Particulate filtration credit: MERV 16 and greater and electronically enhanced filters = Pressure dop calculated at 2x clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Carbon and other gas-phase air cleaners = Clean filter pressure drop at fan system design condition
Biosafety cabinet = Pressure drop of device at fan system design condition
Energy recovery device, other than coil runaround loop = (550 x Energy Recovery Effectiveness) - 125 Pa for each airstream
Coil runaround loop = 150 Pa for each airstream
Evaporative humidifier/cooler in series with another cooling coil = Pressure drop of device 
Sound attenuation section (fans serving spaces with desgin background noise goals below NC35) = 38Pa
Exhaust system serving fume hoods = 85Pa
Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa
EUI_Solution_LOW_COST:
a. Conduct regular energy audit to identify areas of inefficiency

b. Implement and train energy saving practices among staff and users

c. Design the building to maximize natural lighting and ventilation
EUI_Solution_AVG_COST:
a. Install smart energy management system
(i) Schneider, EcoStruxure

b. Upgrade to LED lighting with daylight and occupancy sensors

c. Implement a building energy mangement system
(i) Honeywell, Enterprise Buildings Integrator

d. Install energy submetering for different zones

e. Install an advanced building analytics platform
(i) BuildingIQ
EUI_Solution_HIGH_COST:
a. Implement a Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) system
(i) Daikin, VRV IV

b. Install high efficiency chillers with heat recovery
Trane, Series E

c. Install a large scale solar PV system

d. Implement a microgrid system with AI driven energy optimization
Air_Side_Efficiency_Solution_LOW_COST:
a. Optimize air handling unit (AHU) schedules based on occupancy patterns

b. Implement regular maintenance and cleaning of HVAC components

c. Optimize air distribution through proper zoning and balancing

d. Implement a comprehensive air quality management plan

e. Design for maximum natural ventilation in common areas
Air_Side_Efficiency_Solution_AVG_COST:
a. Install Variable Speed Drives (VSD) on AHU fans
(i) ABB ACH580

b. Upgrade to high efficiency air filters
(i) Camfil, Hi Flo XLT
c. Install demand controlled ventilation with CO2 sensors.

d. Implement an advanced AHU control system
(i) Siemens Desigo CC

e. Install ultra low pressure drop air distribution

f. Implement advanced airflow measurement and control system
(i) EBTRON GTx116P
Air_Side_Efficiency_Solution_HIGH_COST:
a. Implement a demand controlled ventillation with CO2 sensors

b. Install energy recovery (ERVS)

c. Install a dedicated outdoor air system (DOAS)

d. Implement displacement ventilation in large spaces like auditoriums

e. Install an AI driven HVAC optimization system
ETTV_Solution_LOW_COST:

b. Optimise building orientation to minimize solar heat gain

c. Implement strategic landscaping for natural shading

d. Optimize building form to minimize surface area to sun

f. Implement biophillic design principles for natural cooling

b. Apply solar control window filmd
(i) 3M Prestige Series

c. Install dynamic glazing
(i) View, Dynamic Glass

d. Develop a bio  responsive facade with living components
ETTV_Solution_HIGH_COST:

b. Implement a double skin facade with ventilated cavity

c. Install Vacuum Insulated Panels (VIPs) in walls

d. Upgrade to double glazed windows (low E)
(i) Guardian, SunGuard

Laboratory and vivarium exhaust systems in high-rise buildings = 60Pa/30m of vertical duct exceeding 25m

Deduction
Systems with central dooling device = 150Pa
Systems without central heating device = 75Pa
